new_entries.title: Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 is in public preview for GitHub Copilot
new_entries.content: Claude Sonnet 4.5, Anthropic’s most advanced model for coding and real-world agents, is now rolling out in GitHub Copilot to Copilot Pro, Pro+, Business, and Enterprise. From our early testing, the model brings major upgrades in tool orchestration, context editing, and domain-specific capabilities. A_4.5.mov Availability in GitHub Copilot Copilot Chat Claude Sonnet 4.5 will be available for Copilot Pro, Pro+, Business, and Enterprise. You’ll be able to select the model in the Copilot Chat model picker from: Visual Studio Code in chat, ask, edit, and agent mode. github.com. GitHub Mobile in iOS and Android. Copilot CLI All users of Copilot Pro, Pro+, Business, and Enterprise will also be able to select Claude Sonnet 4.5 from the new model picker, available in the latest version of the Copilot CLI (v0.0.329). To switch to Claude Sonnet 4.5, update to the latest version with npm install -g @GitHub/copilot, then use the /model command. Enabling access For all use cases, rollout will be gradual, check back soon if you don’t see it yet. Enterprise and Business plan administrators must enable the Claude Sonnet 4.5 policy in Copilot settings. Once enabled, users in that organization will have Claude Sonnet 4.5 available in the Copilot Chat model picker and Copilot CLI. Copilot Free, Pro, and Pro+ users may also bring their own key in Visual Studio Code by selecting Manage Models from the picker, choosing Anthropic, and entering their API key when prompted. Learn more To explore all models available in GitHub Copilot, see our documentation on models and get started with Copilot. Share your feedback Have feedback or questions? Write a comment below to share your experiences and tips.

new_entries.title: Pick the repository and base branch when assigning issues to Copilot
new_entries.content: We're bringing you a range of additional options for assigning Copilot to issues as part of this public preview. When assigning an issue to Copilot coding agent, you can now choose which repository Copilot should work in, pick a starting branch, and provide additional instructions to give it more context. CCA.issue.assign.mp4 Here’s what’s new: Start Copilot assignment in one click: Assign tasks directly to Copilot with the new Assign to Copilot button. This feature makes it easier and faster to start a Copilot assignment with a single click. Pick the target repository: Choose any repository you have access to, even if your issues and code don't live in the same place. Now you can work with Copilot across repositories, so it's easy to start assignments from issues no matter where your code is stored. Pick a starting branch: Choose which branch Copilot should start from. Whether you want Copilot to work off a feature branch, a bug fix branch, or any other starting point, you now have the flexibility to direct Copilot’s work to exactly where you want it. Add additional instructions: Give Copilot more context with optional instructions. You can provide specific guidance, requirements, or extra details to help Copilot understand exactly what you want to accomplish. This makes assignments more precise and helps Copilot deliver results that match your needs. For more details, check out our documentation on assigning Copilot to an issue. 👇 Want to share feedback on this public preview or join the conversation? Please comment below! Disclaimer: The UI for features in public preview is subject to change.

new_entries.title: Upcoming removal of Copilot premium request $0 budgets for enterprise and team accounts
new_entries.content: Starting November 18, 2025, GitHub will begin removing all $0 Copilot premium request budgets for enterprise and team accounts created before August 22, 2025. As a result, premium request paid usage will be governed by your account’s premium request paid usage policy, not a static $0 budget. Who is affected? All enterprise and org accounts with an account-level $0 Copilot premium request budget created before August 22, 2025 are affected. Pro and Pro+ Copilot users are not affected and will continue to have $0 budgets by default. Why are we making this change? Enables granular controls without complexity: Starting in October, each AI tool will have their own dedicated SKUs for tracking and managing premium request usage, beginning with coding agent and Spark. Keeping the $0 budget model would require you to manually create and manage separate $0 budgets for each new AI tool, creating unnecessary administrative burden as we expand our AI capabilities. Simplifies billing: Removing this budget option eliminates friction and manual intervention for admins, letting you scale AI usage with confidence. What do you need to do? To control premium request paid usage, review and update your premium request paid usage policy. You can disable paid usage at any time in your Copilot policy settings. Learn more in our documentation on premium requests. Questions For questions, feedback, and any thoughts, please comment in the discussion below!

new_entries.title: Copilot Auto model selection now available in Visual Studio Code
new_entries.content: Introducing Copilot Auto model selection 🎊 Not sure which model to use? Auto’s got you covered! 🎉 Today, we’re introducing Auto within VS Code’s GitHub Copilot Chat model picker, rolling out to all Copilot Free, Pro, and Pro+ plans, coming soon to Copilot Enterprise and Copilot Business. When you select Auto, you’ll be routed to the best available model at any given time. Auto brings you: Discounted premium request multipliers for Paid Copilot subscribers A mix of premium language models Transparency around which model is used and what it costs Models that are available based on your subscription and model policies Auto currently optimizes for model availability and reliability. You’ll still get access to premium models like Claude Sonnet 4, GPT-5, and others that perform well on complex tasks. At any point, you can move off of Auto onto your preferred model. What’s next? 🚀 We’re just getting started on making your experience better every day. Over time, Auto will factor in your specific task, choosing models that are best for your needs based on a set of criteria. We’ll also expand Auto’s availability to more of your favorite IDEs. Share your feedback ❤️ Join in the comments below to share your feedback on Auto. Learn more About auto model selection VS Code August release notes

new_entries.title: [2025-09-29] Incident Thread
new_entries.content: ❗ An incident has been declared: Disruption with Gemini 2.5 Pro and Gemini 2.0 Flash in Copilot Subscribe to this Discussion for updates on this incident. Please upvote or emoji react instead of commenting +1 on the Discussion to avoid overwhelming the thread. Any account guidance specific to this incident will be shared in thread and on the Incident Status Page.

new_entries.title: 🚀 Now available: Copilot Spaces — A new way to work with context
new_entries.content: Ever wish Copilot understood your project as well as your teammates do? Now it can. With Copilot Spaces, you can bring together the context Copilot needs (e.g. files, pull requests, issues, repos) into "Spaces". The result? Copilot gives you responses that are grounded in the right context for a specific task. Create a space Organize code, files, pull requests, issues and other project context into a space. Add custom instructions to help guide responses. We’ve made some adjustments to how Copilot works with context in Spaces, so context groundedness should be very high. Context is always based on the latest state of your main branch. Files and repositories added to a space are always kept up to date as they change, making Copilot an evergreen expert in your project. Chat with a space Ask Copilot questions grounded in the context of your Space for more accurate and relevant answers. Share it with teammates You can share spaces with other members of your organization. Spaces in the IDE Access your Space context directly from supported IDEs through the remote GitHub MCP Server. 📂 Do more with Spaces and use it to: Generate code Share knowledge Plan projects Some of our favorite use cases ⭐ Answering questions about code: Chris Westra is an engineer on the Spaces team. He grouped all of the code associated with Spaces and added video transcripts from a recorded Spaces session. We use this Space to answer questions about how Spaces works under-the-hood (very meta). 🙂 Standardizing coding standards and best practices: Rahul Zhade works on a team that advises engineers on secure coding practices. He often answers the same questions over-and-over again in Slack, so he set up a Space. It contains the documentation for our standard auth model, how to do cryptography as well as instructions on how to go through the security review process. Writing SQL/KQL queries: Kelly Henckel is a product manager who is very good at writing SQL and KQL queries. She’s created spaces designed to help people self-service writing data queries and creating dashboards. These helpers contain the code for our telemetry schemas as well as example queries. Updating documentation: Holly Kassel is a product manager working on billing and licensing. She’s been updating GitHub’s documentation to be more user-friendly based on questions arriving through our customer support channels and discussion posts. She creates spaces for each new batch of documentation which needs to be updated, links the existing code and documentation hosted in GitHub, and adds instructions and frequently asked questions as context. The space generates updated versions of the documentation which can be easily copied into our docs repo. Please share feedback with us 🤝 We appreciate your feedback. Give Spaces a try and let us know what you think either in this discussion post or through the inline feedback button. 🚀 Try Spaces now Learn more about Spaces: Changelog Documentation Microsoft Learn module - Introduction to Spaces GitHub Skills exercise

new_entries.title: GitHub Copilot Certification Exam Prep: Part One - Let's Get Started ⏯️
new_entries.content: Welcome to Week 1 of the GitHub Copilot certification prep course! This week, we’ll start with some introductory materials and best practices to build a solid foundation for the exam. This discussion is your go-to spot to ask questions, review study guides, and practice exam topics. To give you a clear roadmap, we’ve broken down the course into weekly learning goals as per the exam study guide. Here’s an overview of what to expect, including the key topics and their weightage in the exam. 💡 Week One (Now-Nov 22): Core Knowledge & Responsible AI (22%) Introduction to GitHub Copilot GitHub Copilot plans Responsible AI with GitHub Copilot 🤯 Week Two (Nov 25-29): Copilot Features & Data Handling (30%) GitHub Copilot features How GitHub Copilot works and handles data 🚀 Week Three (Dec 2-6): Prompt Engineering & Productivity (24%) Prompt engineering and Prompt crafting Developer use cases for AI 🎯 Week Four (Dec 9-13): Testing, Security & Privacy (24%) Testing with GitHub Copilot Privacy fundamentals and context exclusions. 🎗️ Remember, top participants will win a GitHub Certification exam voucher! 🎫 So stay engaged, share your insights, and make the most of this opportunity. 👋 Week 2️⃣ of the GitHub Copilot certification prep course is now Live! NotePro Tip: Stay up to date by subscribing to this discussion—don’t miss any key resources or prep tips! 📲 Step One: Prep 📚 Let’s lay the groundwork for your Copilot expertise! Here's your curated resource pack for Week 1. These materials are everything you need to ace this portion of the exam: Microsoft Learn Modules (each of the modules has its own knowledge check exercise) Introduction to GitHub Copilot Get started with GitHub Copilot Responsible AI with GitHub Copilot Copilot plans Introduction to GitHub Copilot Business Introduction to GitHub Copilot Enterprise GitHub Learning Pathways Essentials of GitHub Copilot Videos Getting started with GitHub Copilot GitHub Copilot plans and features (On Demand from Microsoft Reactor) Blogs Responsible AI pair programming with GitHub Copilot GitHub Docs Quickstart for GitHub Copilot Responsible use of GitHub Copilot features Microsoft Ignite (Live Events) - Sessions catalog GitHub Copilot can do that?​ Discover GitHub Copilot's untapped potential in Visual Studio How GitHub Copilot is redefining development in VS Code Step Two: Put Your Knowledge to the Test ⚡ Use the discussion below to share additional study resources and respond to our prep questions Which of the following subscription plans are available for GitHub Copilot? a. GitHub Copilot Free, Pro, and Team b. GitHub Copilot Personal, Business, and Enterprise c. GitHub Copilot Starter, Professional, and Enterprise d. GitHub Copilot Individual, Business, and Enterprise How do you access GitHub Copilot's inline chat? a) Access the inline chat by clicking on the chat icon in the left sidebar of Visual Studio Code. b) Use Ctrl+i on Windows or Command+i on a mac to open the inline chat. c) Access the inline chat by using Alt+i on Windows or Option+i on a mac. d) Type "/chat" anywhere in your code to open the inline chat. What percentage of developers said that GitHub Copilot helps them code faster? a) 70% b) 83% c) 65% d) 90% How does GitHub Copilot work? a) GitHub Copilot uses prompts and natural language text that you type to provide coding suggestions. b) GitHub Copilot uses lights that you type, and it provides suggestions based on what you type. c) GitHub Copilot uses radio language that you type, and it provides suggestions based on what you type. d) GitHub Copilot uses binary code input to generate suggestions. How does GitHub Copilot learn from your prompts? a) It only relies on its pre-existing training data. b) It utilizes various approaches including zero-shot, one-shot, and few-shot learning. c) It requires extensive manual training on specific tasks. d) It cannot learn and adapt based on user interactions. What is the difference between GitHub Copilot Business and GitHub Copilot Enterprise? a) GitHub Copilot Enterprise has code completions, while GitHub Copilot Business does not. b) GitHub Copilot Enterprise has chat in IDE and mobile, while GitHub Copilot Business does not. c) GitHub Copilot Enterprise has an extra layer of personalization, with organization utilizing their own codebase to train GitHub Copilot. d) GitHub Copilot Enterprise has an extra layer of security, with IP indemnity and enterprise-grade security, safety, and privacy. What is the primary goal of Responsible AI? a) To maximize profits from AI systems. b) To develop AI systems as quickly as possible. c) To ensure AI systems are safe, trustworthy, and ethical. d) To replace human decision-making with AI. Engage in the discussion below by sharing your favourite study resources, sharing feedback, and answering prep questions. As a refresher again, we'll be selecting top participants to receive a GitHub Certifications exam voucher 🎫 based on your active participation throughout the prep up weeks. 🚀

new_entries.title: Level Up with Copilot Free! 🚀 Learn, Explore, and Get Certified
new_entries.content: Hey Copilot Explorers! 👋 Get ready! Something exciting is coming your way starting February 10! – an immersive journey that’s packed learning resources and the chance to earn GitHub Copilot certification vouchers! 🎯 We first ran this campaign in December 2024 to help you Get certified with GitHub Copilot and the response has been incredible, and the support we received from the community was nothing short of amazing. It’s been over 50 days since we launched Copilot Free, and by now, we hope you’ve had the chance to explore its powerful features and make it a part of your workflow. Now, with Copilot Free, we know even more of you are eager to dive deeper and unlock the true potential of Copilot! Whether you’re just beginning your journey or looking to level up your AI skills, this structured campaign is your chance to: ✨ Master GitHub Copilot – Learn how to code smarter, faster, and more efficiently. ✨ Tackle Weekly Challenges – Answer the practise questions and take weekly learning surveys/challenges. ✨ Engage with the Community – Share tips, experiences, and success stories with fellow developers. ✨ Get Certified! – Top participants will receive certification vouchers Week 1: Getting started! 🔢 Week 2: Features & Data handling Week 3: Prompt Engineering & Productivity Week 4: Testing, Security & Privacy 📅 Campaign Highlights We promise you this that each week will unlock a new layer of knowledge, from responsible AI to prompt engineering and security best practices. With our weekly study modules, you’ll navigate through essential topics that empower you to master GitHub Copilot. Here’s what’s coming your way, week by week: Curated Study Materials Interactive Q&A Sessions Hands-on Practice Exercises Surveys (We want to learn more about your Copilot learning journey) NoteSubscribe to this discussion to stay updated on weekly resources and prep tips! 💡Week 1: Getting started! 🔢 - GitHub Copilot Free learning and certification prep Now Live! 🤯 Week Two (Feb 17–21): Copilot Features & Data Handling 🚀 Week Three (Feb 24–28): Prompt Engineering & Productivity 🎯 Week Four (Mar 3–7): Testing, Security & Privacy 🎁 Bonus: Active participants will have a chance to win exclusive certification vouchers! Let’s make the most of Copilot Free—together! 🙌

new_entries.title: Copilot Chat Now Generally Available on GitHub  🎉
new_entries.content: We’re excited to announce that Copilot Chat on GitHub is now generally available! These features are accessible to all users with the following plans: Copilot Free: Includes access to Copilot Chat on GitHub.com. Copilot Pro and Copilot Business: Include full access to Copilot Chat. Manage Your Copilot Settings You can manage these features using the following resources: Copilot Settings for Free and Pro Users Copilot Organization Policies for Business Users Updates to Terms These features are now covered under the standard GitHub Terms: GitHub Copilot Pro Terms GitHub Copilot Business Terms Note: They are no longer governed by the GitHub Preview Terms. Enhanced Copilot Chat Indexing To help you get the most out of Copilot Chat, we’ve removed the limits on the number of repositories you can index to improve Copilot Chat responses. Thank You for Your Feedback Your insights during the public preview were instrumental in improving these features. If you have additional feedback, please share it in the comments below. We can’t wait to see how these features enhance your development workflows! 🚀
